marketNews.title: Indonesia Inflation Rises to 2.75% Amid Rice Price Surge
marketNews.content: The Indonesian Consumer Price Index (CPI) recorded an increase to 2.75% year-on-year (YoY) in February 2024, up from 2.57% YoY in January, surpassing the consensus expectation of 2.6% YoY and marking the highest level since November 2023. The inflation rise in February 2024 was driven by higher staple food prices, such as rice, which rose +5.32% month-on-month (MoM) and +19.28% YoY. The rice price surge occurred amid rising paddy prices at the farmer level. The Bureau of Statistics (BPS) noted that dry paddy harvest prices increased +4.86% MoM and +27.14% YoY in February 2024, while milled dry paddy prices rose +6.13% MoM and +33.48% YoY. In addition to rice, the Deputy Head of BPS Production Statistics, M. Habibullah, said chicken meat, chili, and sugar prices were also major contributors to February inflation. According to Danamon Bank economist Irman Faiz, the food price increase in February was also driven by seasonal patterns ahead of Ramadan. On a monthly basis, CPI inflation reached 0.37% MoM in February 2024 (vs. 0.04% MoM in January). Core inflation in February was 1.68% YoY (vs. expectation of 1.71% YoY), stable compared to the previous month and the lowest since December 2021. Since the start of the year, Indonesia's CPI inflation reached 0.34% year-to-date (YTD) by February 2024. Bank Indonesia targets inflation for 2024 in the range of 1.5%-3.5%. The government expects rice prices to start falling as rice import quotas increase from 2 million tons to 3.6 million tons in 2024 and as the main harvest season begins in March 2024. Successful containment of rice prices to more normal levels will reduce inflationary pressure. Conversely, if rice prices remain high, it could suppress consumer purchasing power and negatively affect consumer-focused issuers, especially those targeting lower-middle-income segments. Related stocks: $MYOR, $INDF, $ICBP, $UNVR, $HMSP, $GGRM, $WIIM

marketNews.title: Constitutional Court Removes Parliamentary Threshold
marketNews.content: The Constitutional Court on Thursday (29 February) struck down the parliamentary threshold of 4% of valid national votes, deeming it inconsistent with the principles of popular sovereignty, electoral justice, and the legal certainty guaranteed by the constitution. However, the removal of the parliamentary threshold will not apply to the 2024 election, but will take effect for the 2029 election.

tickerNews.title: Adaro Energy Indonesia Reports FY23 Net Profit Down 34.2% YoY but Beats Estimates
tickerNews.content: Adaro Energy Indonesia reported a net profit of US$1.64 billion (-34.2% YoY) for 2023, equal to 110% of the estimate and exceeding consensus. Revenue fell -19.6% YoY to US$6.5 billion, yet still above the 104% estimate. The revenue decline was caused by a decrease in average selling price (ASP) of -26% YoY. Coal sales volume grew +7% YoY to 65.71 million tons. From an operational perspective, 2023 production volume rose +4.8% YoY to 65.88 million tons, with the strip ratio increasing to 4.35 x (vs. 2022: 3.75 x).

tickerNews.title: Adaro Minerals Indonesia Reports FY23 Net Profit Up 33.8% YoY, Beats Estimates
tickerNews.content: Adaro Minerals Indonesia recorded a net profit of US$441 million (+33.8% YoY) for 2023, surpassing 127% of the consensus estimate. Revenue grew +19.6% YoY to US$1.1 billion (109% of estimate), supported by coal sales volume increasing +39.4% YoY, which offset a decline in ASP of -14% YoY. Operationally, 2023 production volume rose +52% YoY to 5.11 million tons, and the strip ratio increased to 3.66 x (vs. 2022: 2.47 x).

tickerNews.title: Pertamina Geothermal Energy Reports FY23 Net Profit Up 28.5% YoY, Beats Estimates
tickerNews.content: Pertamina Geothermal Energy posted a net profit of US$163.6 million (+28.5% YoY) for 2023, equal to 109% of the estimate and exceeding consensus. The result was driven by revenue growth of +5.2% YoY to US$406.3 million (101% of estimate) across all operating areas, including Kamojang (+3.8% YoY), Ulubelu (+7.2% YoY), and Lumut Balai (+8.7% YoY). Net profit growth was also supported by a moderate increase in cost of goods sold (+3.3% YoY), a sharp rise in financial income (+1,744% YoY), and other income (+190% YoY).

tickerNews.title: Elnusa Reports FY23 Net Profit of IDR 503.1 Billion, Slightly Below Estimates
tickerNews.content: Elnusa recorded a net profit of IDR 503.1 billion (+33.1% YoY) for 2023, equal to 90% of the estimate and below consensus expectations. The result was driven by revenue growth of +2.1% YoY to IDR 12.6 trillion, mainly supported by a +39.2% YoY increase in oil-field services revenue to IDR 1.4 trillion (105% of estimate). Cost of goods sold remained stable.

tickerNews.title: Pantai Indah Kapuk Dua Reports FY23 Net Profit Up 95.4% YoY
tickerNews.content: Pantai Indah Kapuk Dua posted a net profit of IDR 270 billion (+95.4% YoY) for 2023. The result was supported by revenue growth of +273.7% YoY to IDR 2.2 trillion, while cost of goods sold rose sharply by +500.9% YoY to IDR 1.1 trillion.

tickerNews.title: Japfa Comfeed Indonesia Reports FY23 Net Profit Down 31% YoY
tickerNews.content: Japfa Comfeed Indonesia recorded a net profit of IDR 930 billion (-31% YoY) for 2023, equal to 80% of the estimate and below consensus. The decline was caused by operating expenses increasing +7% YoY to IDR 5.2 trillion, while revenue grew only +5% YoY to IDR 51 trillion (101% of estimate), resulting in a net profit margin of 1.8% (vs. 2.9% in 2022).

tickerNews.title: HEAL Targets 16.8% Revenue Growth in 2024 and Announces IDR 2 Trillion Capex
tickerNews.content: HEAL's Chief Financial Officer Yulisar Khiat said the company targets revenue growth of +16.8% in 2024. To achieve this, HEAL allocates capex of IDR 2 trillion in 2024, aimed at building five new hospitals in IKN, Madiun, Pasuruan, PIK 2, and Pekanbaru, bringing the total number of hospitals to 52 by the end of 2024. Additionally, the capex will be used to increase bed capacity in existing hospitals from 4,000 beds to 7,000 beds.
